pullRequest.body:
We compute the cardinality of each node in an inverse system `F i` indexed by a well-order in which every map between successive nodes has constant fiber `X i`, and every limit node is the `limit` of the inverse subsystem formed by all previous nodes. (To avoid importing `Cardinal`, we in fact construct a bijection rather than stating the result in terms of `Cardinal.mk`.)

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
```

</details>
Amazing! You get to not import directed systems of modules in model theory anymore. ðŸŽ‰
I think this has little to do with `SuccOrder` now. What about renaming the file to `Order.DirectedInverseSystem`?

> I think this has little to do with `SuccOrder` now. What about renaming the file to `Order.DirectedInverseSystem`?

Sounds reasonable to me. The key transfinite recursion construction [SuccOrder.prelimitRecOn](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/SuccPred/Limit.html#SuccOrder.prelimitRecOn) used in the inverse system file is introduced in SuccPred/Limit, but the inverse system file doesn't have to stay in the same directory.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11729455921/job/32675132482)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11729455921/job/32675132756)
Thanks a lot for the review! Resolved comments are addressed in [1417e55](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18067/commits/1417e554cbaff7daa32c0ae3644a7955dedad21e).

Thanks!

maintainer merge

```suggestion
Now our task reduces to the recursive construction of a *natural* family of bijections for each `i`.
```

```suggestion
We can prove that a natural family over all `l â‰¤ i` (`Iic i`) extends to a natural family over
```
I think?

```suggestion
`Iic iâº` (where `iâº = succ i`), but at a limit node, recursion stops working: we have natural families over all `Iic j`
```

```suggestion
we can clearly take the union to get a natural family that extends them all. If a maximal
```
Could you move the definition of `DirectedSystem` to this file?
and then import this file into Mathlib.Algebra.DirectLimit? That file currently probably doesn't require/import as much order theory as this file. Let's see whether we get a large-import alert ...

> and then import this file into Mathlib.Algebra.DirectLimit?

Yes exactly

> That file currently probably doesn't require/import as much order theory as this file. Let's see whether we get a large-import alert ...

I believe it should be fine. You are not importing a huge lot here, and Algebra.DirectLimit is supposed to be quite advanced
You're right, it appears that Algebra.DirectLimit doesn't get any new imports!

```suggestion
local postfix:max "âº" => succ -- Note: conflicts with `PosPart` notation
```

... then this works
```suggestion
def piEquivSucc : âˆ€ j : Iic iâº, F j â‰ƒ piLT X j :=
```
and also below

nit:
```suggestion
  equiv (i : s) : F i â‰ƒ piLT X i
```
IIUC this commutes with the projection maps, right? Can you prove it?
Yes, I was just lazy ...
Do you want to do it in this PR? Otherwise I'm happy with leaving it as a TODO

Done in [b6bdb35](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18067/commits/b6bdb35215743314c067d33570fd00aa6a15e440); just requires a bit of refactoring. A bit unexpected though that I need to use `pEquivOn_apply_eq` (i.e. uniqueness of `pEquivOn`) once more.

I know you are just moving them, but why are those primed actually? Let's fix that here while we're at it
```suggestion
  map_self â¦ƒiâ¦„ (x : F i) : f i i le_rfl x = x
  map_map â¦ƒk j iâ¦„ (hij : i â‰¤ j) (hjk : j â‰¤ k) (x : F k) : f hjk (f hij x) = f (hij.trans hjk) x
```
Then we are sure that `DirectedSystem` and `InverseSystem` are exactly alike

I also moved the unprimed lemmas `map_self` and `map_map`, which makes `(f : âˆ€ i j, i â‰¤ j â†’ G i â†’ G j)` an explicit variable. I can try to do what you say, but the change to `map_self` and one more explicit argument in both lemmas probably mean that many downstream files will break. If that happens it's probably better done in another PR.
Please try, and we can move it to a separate PR if too much breaks.

[A total of 4 files break](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/9b35f99f27c65f6d61b8695d5e12f1f6bb652178), though I didn't try to push the refactor further by changing the statements of [Module.DirectedSystem.map_self](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/DirectLimit.html#Module.DirectedSystem.map_self) etc.
Should I merge the test branch into this PR?
Please do. It looks like tiny breakage

```suggestion
    Iio j i :=
```

```suggestion
    Ioo j i :=
```
is what you mean, I assume

Is this a particularly useful definition? As the proof shows, it's basically just a direct application of `not_covBy_iff`. Maybe it could be stated in terms of `covBy` so that it doesn't need to be generalized to all the different `IsLimit` spellings?

It's used to construct data and `Classical.indefiniteDescription` is quite long to write ... in total used 5 times in the DirectedInverseSystem file. I expect this to be useful generally for transfinite induction arguments: at a limit ordinal `i`, if for each `k < i` you already constructed a family of objects over all `j < k`, you can obtain a family over all `j < i` by choosing a `k` in between for each `j < i`.
What do you think about calling it `iooOfLT`?
Honestly, I think the name `mid` is fine.

Maybe nitpicky, but why not use `Î ` in the definition?
```suggestion
abbrev piLT (X : Î¹ â†’ Type*) (i : Î¹) := Î  l : Iio i, X l
```
I think the ship has sailed and we are not using `Î ` anymore

Yeah, I think mathport translated all Î  to âˆ€. (The pretty printer does neither; it prints `(i : Î¹) â†’ f i`.) [DFinsupp](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/DFinsupp/Basic.html#DFinsupp) still uses a Î â‚€ notation though. I intend to use âˆ€ but may inadvertently put Î  occasionally.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: cardinalities in specific inverse systems

source.title: feat: cardinality of `Field.Emb` for infinite extensions

nodes.body: Thanks a lot for the review! Resolved comments are addressed in [1417e55](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18067/commits/1417e554cbaff7daa32c0ae3644a7955dedad21e).
Amazing! You get to not import directed systems of modules in model theory anymore. ðŸŽ‰
I think this has little to do with `SuccOrder` now. What about renaming the file to `Order.DirectedInverseSystem`?

> I think this has little to do with `SuccOrder` now. What about renaming the file to `Order.DirectedInverseSystem`?

Sounds reasonable to me. The key transfinite recursion construction [SuccOrder.prelimitRecOn](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/SuccPred/Limit.html#SuccOrder.prelimitRecOn) used in the inverse system file is introduced in SuccPred/Limit, but the inverse system file doesn't have to stay in the same directory.

Thanks!

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.
